posts.name: Beck's Cajun Cafe
posts.note: Beck's Cajun Cafe is a bustling counter serve dishing up Cajun and Creole comfort food to the farmers market crowd. You need to make sure order a train wreck which contains Andouille sausage, steak, salami, and onions served on a french baguette with cheese and creole mayo. It's one of my favorite sandwiches in the country. From the Reading Terminal Market website, ‘Bringing a taste of the Big Easy to the City of Brotherly Love, Chef Bill Beck prides himself on the rich, authentic Cajun and Creole flavors that Beck’s Cajun Cafe serves up for breakfast, lunch, and dinner. The experienced restaurateur, three-time Best of Philly winner, and two-time guest chef at James Beard House keeps it casual and classic at Reading Terminal. Naturally, Beck’s offers New Orleans classics like gumbo, jambalaya, étouffée, and the beloved muffuletta sandwich, but they also bring a Cajun spin to morning with breakfast po’ boys like steak and egg with salsa and a taste of the South with deep-fried mac and cheese and shrimp and crawdad pasta. Stop by on Wednesdays or Sundays for freshly fried beignets to go with your morning coffee. Can’t make it in until lunch? Try the Train Wreck Po’ Boy, stuffed with andouille, steak, salami, cheese, and onion. Wreck or no, it’s worth it.’ NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Beiler's Donuts and Beiler's Bakery
posts.note: Beiler's Donuts and Beiler's Bakery is the destination in Reading Terminal Market for baked goods, including Pennsylvania Dutch classics and a variety of housemade donuts. The blueberry or apple fritter is a must have. They are in my top three favorite fritters in the country. Any other donut you choose won't be a bad thing here. From their website, ‘Our doughnuts are made fresh daily on location! Using a recipe that has been in the family for generations, we hand-roll each doughnut with care before topping and decorating each doughnut individually. Our doughnuts are made using only the best ingredients and are fried using vegetable oil with zero trans fats. Many of our cream fillings are made fresh at our main headquarters in Lancaster County.’ NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Bing Bing Dim Sum
posts.note: Bing Bing Dim Sum serves Chinese plates with a Jewish twist, and festive scorpion bowls are served at this snug, energetic spot. Their food is often informed by tradition, but it’s never defined by it. All that they require of your willing mind and a willing stomach. The owners of Bing Bing Dim Sum also own CheU Noodle Bar, Nunu, and CheU Fishtown. From the Philadelphia Eater website, ‘A sturdy streetside enclosure lines the outside of Bing Bing Dim Sum on E. Passyunk Avenue. Go for the turnip cake, cheesesteak bao, and generous happy hour — stay for the patio heaters, string lights, and ambiance.’

posts.name: CheU Fishtown
posts.note: CheU Fishtown is hip ramen bar with graffitied walls serves noodles and Asian bites, plus beer, wine, and cocktails. Their food is often informed by tradition, but it’s never defined by it. All that they require of your willing mind and a willing stomach. The owners of CheU Fishtown also own CHeU Noodle Bar, Bing Bing Dim Sum, and Nunu. From their website, ‘Cheu Fishtown is our noodle bar focused on Asian-inspired noodle bowls, soups + small plates with a full bar serving beer, wine, sake, and cocktails.’ From the Philadelphia Eater website, ‘Ben Puchowitz and Shawn Darragh of Cheu Noodle Bar and Bing Bing Dim Sum brought their Asian-with-a-Jewish-twist cuisine to Frankford Avenue with Cheu Fishtown. The popular spot for ramen, rice bowls, and dumplings is set in a former horse stable, with a bright red bar and eye-catching decor. And because it’s possible to also order from the sushi spot next door, Nunu, this is a great place to go for an indecisive group.’

posts.name: Dalessandro's Steaks
posts.note: Dalessandro's Steaks is a cheesesteak counter that caters to a local crowd with steaks, hoagies, burgers, and salads. For more than half a century later, they have kept their customers grinning from ear to ear. From their website, ‘The Dalessandro’s Cheesesteak is like no other in Philadelphia. That’s why it’s the people’s and critics’ choice year after year. For starters, it’s fresh – we mean really fresh. When you pull up a barstool and order, all you have to do is look and listen. Produce, bakery, and meat deliveries are going on as you bite into your sandwich. They don’t come once, but throughout the day over and over again. Add the musical symphony of the clanging spatula sound on the grill, and you’re assured the tradition continues. Meat is finely chopped so that the delicious flavor of the cheese and onions finds its way through every piece of meat. It’s the perfect blend of grilled onions, soft roll, and cheese. That’s how we prepare our authentic steaks, and we guarantee it.’

posts.name: Di Bruno Brothers
posts.note: Di Bruno Brothers is an acclaimed gourmet destination supplying meats, cheeses, and prepared foods, plus specialty items. When you visit, you won't go home hungry since whenever you ask about a product, they will give you some to taste. From their website, ‘For over 80 years Di Bruno Bros. has offered nothing but the highest quality products, made with integrity (often in-house), and infused with the story of the people who made them. It’s a story of discovery, of two brothers, aunts and uncles, of Culinary Pioneers and Philadelphians. And it is that dinner table mentality that has enabled Di Bruno Bros. to not only endure for so long but also to grow and prosper both locally and nationally. And we’re just getting started. So pull up a chair.’ NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Federal Donuts
posts.note: Federal Donuts has buzzy counter serve dishing Korean-style fried chicken, creative donuts & coffee till they run out. From their website, ‘In Philadelphia, the cradle of liberty, Federal Donuts is a hometown hero. The donut shop is an American institution, and Philadelphia’s favorite shop was founded in 2011 by five hungry Philadelphians in South Philadelphia whose lives were changed by donuts. This donut, fried chicken, and coffee shop—from partner/CEO Tom Henneman and partners Steve Cook and Michael Solomonov—is known for its affordable comfort classics in tantalizingly delicious, unexpected flavors that change all the time. The crowds come for donuts first, served either Fancy (glazed and decorated each morning) or Hot Fresh (fried to order and tossed in flavored sugars). Federal Donuts’ twice-fried, super crispy chicken is served with savory dipping sauces, in dry seasonings, or naked. In addition, Federal Donuts serves up its Philly favorite Chicken Sandwich, a twice-fried boneless chicken breast dusted in house ranch seasoning and topped with American cheese, dill pickles, and the shop’s not-so-secret recipe for “Spicy Rooster Sauce,” all on a potato roll.’ NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Han Dynasty - Old City
posts.note: Han Dynasty - Old City serves Sichuan eats, along with a late-night street-food menu (Thursday, Friday, and Saturday) served in grand digs with high ceilings. From their website, ‘Han Dynasty opened its doors in 2007 as a Mother-Son restaurant bringing Sichuan-style spice to the American audience. We’ve grown to 10 locations across Philadelphia and NYC. We are committed to sharing the authentic cuisine of the Sichuan Chinese culture and the tradition behind it. Han Dynasty’s mission encompasses not just serving great food but providing great experiences in our unique locations featuring local art, at our lively bars, and in our private events. Our delivery game is on point, too, getting to you quickly with the same care and attention you find when dining in our restaurants.’ From the Philadelphia Eater website, ‘Han Dynasty doesn’t play when it comes to spice. The items on its Sichuan menu are rated on a spice scale of one to 10 — 10 being tongue-numbing — to warn customers what they’re getting themselves into. Standouts include the dan dan noodles, kung pao chicken, spicy cucumbers, and spring rolls. Takeout and delivery are available at all six Philly-area locations, and some offer onsite dining.’ NOTE: They have multiple locations.
posts.rcmmnd: Best Chinese restaurant in every state from MSN website

posts.name: Isgro's Bakery
posts.note: Isgro's Bakery is the venerable bake shop turning out cannoli, cakes, cookies, custards, tarts and other Italian pastries. I go there for their cannoli's, but all their pastries look delicious. From their website, ‘Philadelphia’s legendary Italian Market bakery makes pastry dreams come true. Over a century of baking obsession, repetition, and precision yields award-winning cannoli, cookies, cakes, and classic Italian sweets. Handmade in small batches and family-run since 1904.’

posts.name: Murph's Bar
posts.note: At Murph's Bar, pennies cover the bar in this comfy Irish pub with an exposed-brick interior and quirky decorations. I read on Alex Hillman's Twitter that 'Murph's on Girard has some of the best Italian food in the city of Philadelphia.' From Bon Appetit magazine's website, 'It’s an Italian red sauce joint inside of an Irish pub. There’s only one guy that works in the kitchen. He cooks everything. He’s from Italy. It’s always slammed. There are hardly any seats. You have to go early on a weeknight if you want to get in without waiting for like...two hours. It’s affordable. There’s a weird, vague Elvis theme.'

posts.name: Nan Zhou Hand Drawn Noodle House
posts.note: Nan Zhou Hand Drawn Noodle House serves noodles that are hand-pulled in-house and added to soups along with stir-fries at this casual Chinatown restaurant. From the Philadelphia Eater website, ‘Go for the hand-drawn and shaved noodles, served in soups or stir-fried dishes, in a number of combinations that should satisfy almost any taste — and then keep coming back to eat through the rest of the menu. Portions are bountiful, and prices are affordable across the board, making Nan Zhou one of Chinatown’s many must-tries.’

posts.name: Nunu
posts.note: Nunu cooks what they like to eat — it’s personal, no matter what they put in front of you. Their food is often informed by tradition, but it’s never defined by it. All that they require of your willing mind and a willing stomach. The owners of Nunu also own CHeU Noodle Bar, Bing Bing Dim Sum, and CHeU Fishtown. Alex Hillman recommends the 'Pork Katsu' sandwich and the impossible burger. From the Philadelphia Eater website, 'Shawn Darragh and Ben Puchowitz of Cheu and Bing Bing Dim Sum are just about ready to debut Nunu, their small, stylish, very red Japanese bar next door to Cheu Fishtown.'

posts.name: Reading Terminal Market
posts.note: Reading Terminal Market is a famous indoor farmer's market offering diverse fare, housewares and area specialties since 1892. There is so much to do and eat while you're here make sure to go hungry. From the Philadelphia Eater website, ‘From Bassett’s Ice Cream to Beiler’s Donuts to El Merkury’s pupusas and Hershel’s pastrami sandwiches, Reading Terminal Market is a giant destination for many of the affordable eats this city has to offer. Whether the mood strikes for a roast pork sandwich from DiNic’s or an Amish-style soft pretzel from Miller’s Twist, the only mistake one can make at Reading Terminal is going there already full.’

posts.name: Revolution Taco
posts.note: Revolution Taco is a casual, counter-serve taqueria featuring unique fillings, including meat, fish, and veggie options. From their website, 'Revolution Taco is the concept of Chef Carolyn Nguyen. With her classically trained chef approach, Carolyn uses the taco shell as a vehicle to create global-inspired dishes as tacos. Some menu highlights include: Korean Beef tacos, Roasted Duck tacos served on a scallion pancake, and our vegan BBQ Cauliflower tacos.' From their website, ‘Revolution Taco is the concept of Chef Carolyn Nguyen. With her classically trained chef approach, Chef Carolyn uses the taco shell as a vehicle to create globally inspired dishes as tacos. Some menu highlights include Korean Beef tacos, Roast Duck tacos served on a scallion pancake, and our vegan BBQ Cauliflower tacos. We have several other vegetarian and vegan options as well. Carolyn and her team will use their culinary knowledge and experience in restaurants and catering to bring the city of Philadelphia a fresh and unique approach to the understated taco by elevating the flavors and presentation of our products. The menu includes not only tacos but also burritos and burrito bowls, hand-made chips accompanied by fresh-made pico de gallo and guacamole, as well as homemade empanadas. We look forward to seeing you enjoy our food and atmosphere.’

posts.name: Silk City
posts.note: Silk City is a renovated diner with an outdoor beer garden serves classics like fried chicken and meatloaf. You should order one or all of these: the duck confit egg roll or the pork and crab pot stickers or meatloaf. From their website, ‘Silk City Diner, Lounge, and Garden has a long history in Philadelphia. The diner car was built in 1952 by the Paterson Dining Company in Paterson, New Jersey. At the time, Paterson had a thriving silk manufacturing industry and was nicknamed the “Silk City.” Hence, the diner car, also manufactured in Paterson, was dubbed a “Silk City Diner.” By 1954, the diner was installed next to a cocktail lounge in Philadelphia at 5th & Spring Garden and began serving Philadelphians brunch, dinner, and nightly entertainment happily since.’

posts.name: South Philly Barbacoa
posts.note: South Philly Barbacoa serves unassuming Mexican eatery specializing in traditional slow-cooked barbacoa-style tacos and toppings. You need to get the pork and the lamb tacos. From the Philadelphia Eater website, ‘This year (2022), Cristina Martinez brought home the James Beard Award for Best Chef, Mid-Atlantic, making her excellent casual counter-service Mexican eatery — spotlighted on Chef’s Table and Ugly Delicious — a local landmark of which every Philadelphian is uber proud. Outdoor and indoor dining is available, but the barbacoa, especially when purchased by the half kilo with housemade tortillas, consomé, and all the fixings, also travels extremely well. No delivery, cash only, and it’s open Saturday and Sundays from 5 a.m. until they sell out.’
posts.hrs: Closed Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday

posts.name: Standard Tap
posts.note: Standard Tap is a multilevel spot featuring a rotating menu of American eats and a variety of local beers on tap. From their website, ‘When Standard Tap opened its doors in December of 1999, our goal was simple: to create a neighborhood tavern that featured great beer and wholesome food. With that in mind, we offer a draft-only beer selection that highlights the vast array of styles crafted by breweries located in Pennsylvania, New Jersey, and Delaware. Our food menu both complements the beer and expands the notion of what pub food can be. “The gastropub that started it all with a focus on great local craft beer and serious food still captures a certain super-bar magic in the moody, rambling rooms of its Northern Liberties tavern,” mentions Craig Laban in his revisit to Standard Tap. Our menu features a wide selection of hearty dishes using seasonal ingredients and local produce. We are proud to support initiatives like Pennsylvania’s Buy Fresh Buy Local movement and urban agriculture from Greensgrow Farms.’

posts.name: Tommy Di Nic's
posts.note: Tommy Di Nic's crowds pack this venerable Reading Terminal Market sandwich counter celebrated for its roast pork and make sure to get sharp provolone on your sandwich. Their roast pork with aged provolone is world famous, and the meatball or the roast beef subs aren't bad either. From the Reading Terminal Market website, ‘Tommy Nicolosi’s culinary legacy began in 1918 when his Grandfather Gaetano opened a butcher shop in South Philly. On occasion, Gaetano would cook big specialty roasts for customers in the garage out back. This eventually led to an off-shoot sandwich business, and in the late 1970s, DiNic’s Roast Pork and Beef was born. Tommy DiNic’s is now in its fourth generation, as Tommy owns and runs the shop with his son, Joey. With a deep respect for the past and an eager eye on the future, Joey has built upon DiNic’s lineup of classic Italian sandwiches to include new favorites like the slow-roasted brisket of beef and Italian-style pulled pork. The Nicolosis’ attention to detail, dedication to sourcing quality ingredients, and reverence for the slow, everything-from-scratch process of their old-world brethren has landed them huge points with customers, aficionados, and the media alike. Following appearances on the Travel Channel’s Man vs. Food and Best Sandwich in America, the DiNic’s Roast Pork Sandwich was crowned the Best Sandwich in America in 2013.’

posts.name: Umai Umai
posts.note: Umai Umai is n inventive sushi, specialty rolls, and hot entrees are offered in contemporary, intimate surroundings. From the Philadelphia Eater website, ‘Open since 2006, the cozy Umai Umai covers all the sushi must-haves, from simple rolls like spicy salmon to inventive combinations like the “krakken” with shrimp tempura, eel, avocado, soft shell crab, cherries, aioli, and almond. Come with a bottle of wine; it’s BYOB.’

posts.name: Vedge
posts.note: Vedge is a restaurant serving inventive vegan and vegetarian small plates in a charming old mansion. From the Philadelphia Eater website, 'Rich Landau and Kate Jacoby reinvented meatless dining in Philly by making vegetables — not meat substitutes — the star at Vedge, an elegant eatery set in a former mansion. Through culinary skill and maybe a little magic, mushrooms become ribbons of pasta and radishes impersonate sushi.' Also, more from the Vedge website, 'A Vegetable Restaurant by James Beard-nominated Chefs Rich Landau and Kate Jacoby; Vedge offers an exciting dining experience inspired by seasonal vegetables since 2011. Housed in the historic Tiger Building in Center City Philadelphia, the elegant brownstone home is an intimate setting for inventive vegetable cooking. The Bar features natural wines, plenty of craft beers, and a creative cocktail list, all selected to complement the wide range of tastes through the dinner and dessert menus. Vedge serves dinner seven nights a week and is available for private parties of various sizes.'
